docs.lead_paragraph: Viagra, the impotence pill, may be dangerous to more people than previously reported, a finding that has prompted two cardiology groups to urge doctors to exercise caution when prescribing the drug. In light of this and other information, Public Citizen, a consumer group, petitioned the Federal Food and Drug Administration yesterday to review Viagra's side effects and strengthen its warning label.

headline.main: Heart Groups Urge Caution On Viagra

docs.abstract: Consumer group Public Citizen petitions Food and Drug Administration to review side effects of impotence drug Viagra and strengthen its warning label in light of recent warnings from American College of Cardiology and American Heart Assn that pill may be dangerous to more people than previously reported (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It took Diana, a 34-year-old recovering heroin addict from the Bronx, exactly 95 days to wean herself from methadone at a residential clinic on Manhattan's Lower East Side last year. ''I counted every day,'' she says. ''On Dec. 8, they announced I was drug free. It was the greatest feeling in my life.'' Diana's success in getting off methadone in a little over three months would seem to support the Giuliani administration's plan to move 2,000 heroin addicts off methadone at city hospitals -- an initiative grounded in a belief that most addicts would need only about 90 days to achieve total abstinence.

headline.main: Few Successes to Back Mayor's Methadone Limits

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Oregon officials announced today that eight people in the state had died after taking lethal medications prescribed under the law allowing doctor-assisted suicide for terminally ill people, which took effect last November. Two other people who were certified as terminally ill and who had received state authorization to take the drugs died before doing so, according to a report released by the Oregon Health Division.

headline.main: Legal Suicide Has Killed 8, Oregon Says
